title: A SAVANNAH ORIGINAL: Critz Jr. brings home car from 1911 open-wheel race
text:

Dale Critz Jr. sits behind the wheel of his 1911 E-M-F Model 30 race car No. 33, which will be used as a pace car in the Savannah Speed Classic on Saturday at Grand Prize of America road course on Hutchinson Island.
Back | Next Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News - Dale Critz Jr. stands in front of his 1911 EMF Racer which will be used as a pace car in the Savannah Speed Classic on Oct. 24. Back | Next Dale Critz Jr., president of the Critz Auto Group, smiles as he shows his 1911 E-M-F race car to a customer.
Back | Next Josh Galemore/Savannah Morning News
Dale Critz Jr. sits behind the wheel of his 1911 E-M-F No. 33 race car, which will be used as a pace car in the Savannah Speed Classic on Saturday on Hutchinson Island.
By Nathan Dominitz
D ale Critz Jr. bought a used car for $220,000 that doesn’t have a fancy navigation system or an AM radio or even windshield wipers.
Not necessary. There’s no windshield.
“Or cup holders,” Critz noted.
What the car does have is history, Savannah history. The 1911 E-M-F No. 33 car competed in the final year of what locals call the Great Savannah Races — the American Grand Prize open-wheel automobile races that sped along city streets more than 100 years ago.
“I wanted this car because I thought that Savannah ought to have one of the cars that raced in the Great Savannah Races,” said Critz, a native of the Hostess City and the president of the Critz Auto Group. “There’s been a lot written about (E-M-F race cars). They were a big deal in the racing world in 1908, ’10 and ’11.”
Racing eventually came back many generations later to the Coastal Empire, with the Savannah Speed Classic this week on Hutchinson Island the biggest annual competition. It’s partnered with the Hilton Head Island (S.C.) Motoring Festival & Concours d’Elegance on Oct. 30-Nov. 1, which is geared to static displays of vintage cars.
Critz BMW has sponsored the Savannah event for years, but what’s new is Critz actually will be driving an artifact as a pace car during ceremonies around noon Saturday. He will have goggles, a helmet, driving gloves and a passenger in the left-side seat where a mechanic sat out of necessity during races. Hold on tight, Mayor Edna Jackson, as the car didn’t come with seat belts, either.
Critz will literally crank up the car to as fast as safety parameters and the mayor will allow. For a sense of how fast the car motored in its brief racing prime, the Nov. 27, 1911 race was won by E-M-F, No. 35, which averaged a little over 58 mph for 171 miles on the 17-mile, rectangular course framed by Montgomery Cross Road and White Bluff roads, Waters Avenue and what is now Victory Drive.
E-M-F — which stood for founders Barney Everitt, William Metzger and Walter Flanders — sent three Model 30 racers from its Detroit factory to Savannah in 1911 for one of the preliminary events for lighter cars with smaller engines. E-M-F, despite derogatory nicknames such as “Every Morning Fix-It” and “Every Mechanical Fault” in these early days of the auto industry, had reason to boast. The trio finished 1-2-3 in the Tiedeman Trophy Race, named for Savannah mayor and racing supporter George Tiedeman.
Long road to travel
E-M-F didn’t last long, as Studebaker bought the company in 1912. The No. 33 car, however, which finished third that November day, went into retirement and was discovered in the 1980s in a New York barn by auto collector Gordon Matson of New Hampshire. He brought it “home” to Savannah in 2008 for the Hilton Head/Savannah Historics.
Dale Critz Jr. is a car guy, too, since birth, as his grandfather opened the first Critz dealership in January 1939 and his father followed in the family business. He didn’t consider himself a serious car collector, though he owns an eclectic mix with a 1949 GMC pickup truck, a 2002 BMW Z8 roadster and a 1958 Isetta microcar (or “bubble car”).
“I’ve got a few old cars, nothing else like this,” said Critz, who samples his wares by driving a 2016 Mercedes-Benz E63.
Collecting got more serious as he pursued the No. 33 race car with Savannah in its origin story. Critz said he doesn’t know of other cars still existing from Savannah’s turn-of-the-century races except for one in an Indianapolis museum and another he heard about in Sweden.
“If there was going to be a car in Savannah that raced in Savannah, this was our best chance,” he said last week. “So that’s why I bought it.”
It wasn’t that easy. Matson put the car up for auction in March during a car show in Amelia Island, Fla. Critz had participated in art auctions and, for his job, in wholesale car auctions where writing a big check comes with the territory.
“That’s inventory. That’s part of business,” Critz said. “This is all emotion.”
The No. 33, among the most publicized vehicles at the auction, was projected to sell for $150,000 to $175,000, though that range seemed high for the E-M-F market, Critz said. And that’s for the car as is, driven off the lot with no warranty.
He was hoping to spend less, but when another bidder by telephone, apparently from Spain, jumped into the fray, the price kept going up.
“If somebody else from Savannah was buying it, I’d have probably let them buy it,” he said, laughing.
He felt, however, that he couldn’t let this rare opportunity pass. The dealer made the deal.
“A number of folks have said yes, it went for over the deal, but given what it was, it was a good price for the seller and a good price for the buyer,” Critz said. “I shouldn’t lose money on it if I ever wanted to get rid of it. I don’t know why I’d get rid of it unless somebody else in Savannah wanted to buy it.”
But it’s not an investment to him. A pricey toy, certainly, but it’s a piece of history that is shiny and smooth with brass and leather parts. It’s got gauges and tube tires and even a working clock. Above all, it is very cool to drive.
“No question,” he said. “This is a race car. Race cars were meant to be driven.”
SAVANNAH SPEED CLASSIC
PARTY SCHEDULE
THURSDAY: Pace Lap Party, 5:30-8 p.m., Ellis Square at City Market, featuring cars and drivers. Free.
FRIDAY: Riverfront Wine Dinner featuring grand marshal Skip Barber, 6:30 p.m., Bohemian Hotel Savannah Riverfront. $125 per person.
RACING SCHEDULE
At Grand Prize of America road course, Hutchinson Island; presented by Mingledorff’s Inc. Schedule subject to change.
FRIDAY: Qualifying sessions 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.; hot laps, 11:15 a.m. (45 minutes); lunch/track touring, noon. Bob Woodman Tire International/American Challenge 3:45 p.m.; hot laps, 4:20 p.m. (30 minutes).
SATURDAY: Qualifying and racing sessions 8 a.m. to 5:15 p.m.; manufacturer corporate laps, 10:40 a.m.; hot laps, 11:10 a.m. (30 minutes); lunch/track touring, 11:40 a.m., followed by pre-race ceremonies, national anthem with Savannah Children’s Choir, race commander Mayor Edna Jackson; BRM Enduro H/P/GTM, 1:10 p.m.; hot laps, 4:15 p.m. and 5:45 p.m. (each 30 minutes).
SUNDAY: Racing 9 a.m. to 4:05 p.m.; to BRM GTC Enduro Challenge, 9 a.m.; hot laps, 10:40 a.m. (20 minutes); lunch/track touring, 11-noon; BRM Vintage Enduro Challenge, 12:30 p.m.; hot laps, 1:40 and 3:10 p.m. (each 30 minutes) and 4:40 p.m. (25 minutes).
INFORMATION: For more details, ticket prices and a full schedule of events for the 2015 Savannah Speed Classic, go to www.SavannahSpeedClassic.com . For more on the Hilton Head Island (S.C.) Motoring Festival & Concours d’Elegance on Oct. 30-Nov. 1, go to http://www.hhiconcours.com.
